694527.trustfund: TF027985-DEBT AND DEBT SERVICE REDUCTION PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Bulgaria - Debt and Debt Service Reduction
            Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Debt and Debt Service Reduction (DDSR)
            Loan in Bulgaria. The primary objective of the DDSR was to
            reduce Bulgaria's debt overhang through a significant
            reduction in its total debt burden. The DDSR operation can
            be judged a success. Implementation of the project was
            satisfactory. The performance of the Bank was good. The Bank
            played an important advisory role in the design, formulation
            and evaluation of the menu of options of the operation. The
            performance of the borrower was satisfactory, especially
            given the political changes. The DDSR agreement was
            successfully completed in a relatively short time and has
            largely achieved its immediate objectives. However, the loan
            accomplished less in advancing pivotal long-term reform and
            several core development issues remain to be tackled.
            Several key lessons have emerged from the Bulgarian DDSR
            experience that may be of broader relevance to other
            countries in the process of restructuring their commercial
            debt. First, a country's ability to meet its external
            debt obligations on a sustainable basis depends on progress
            in restructuring the economy and restoring the basis for
            economic growth during the breathing space provided in the
            first few years of a DDSR agreement. Second, seeking a clear
            picture of available external financing should come before
            agreeing on the specific terms of the DDSR. The Bulgarian
            experience suggests that while pursuing policies that ensure
            the availability of sufficient resources for its debt
            reduction operation, a country should also explicitly
            incorporate its objective for debt reduction into the deal.
            Finally, directing macroeconomic policies toward preserving
            financial stability throughout the DDSR process is vital.

18224999.admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

0.cdata!: Debt and Debt Service Reduction Loan

18224999.trustfund: TF027985-DEBT AND DEBT SERVICE REDUCTION PROJECT

repnme.cdata!: Bulgaria - Debt and Debt Reduction Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Debt and Debt Service Reduction Loan
            Project and related measures will reimburse the Government
            of Bulgaria for a portion of the upfront costs of the recent
            debt and debts services reduction (DDSR) agreement on the
            restructuring of about US$8.1 billion in public external
            debt - including about US$1.9 billion in past due interest.
            The Bank's support will be part of a joint effort with
            the International Monetary Fund (IMF) to replenish partially
            Bulgaria's international reserves used to finance the
            upfront costs of the DDSR agreement. The proposed measures
            are: (i) a Debt and Debt Service Reduction Loan to the
            Republic of Bulgaria for US$125 million to reimburse a
            portion of the cost of the principal and interest collateral
            of the instruments and/or the debt buyback; and (ii) set
            asides of US$75 million out of a proposed Financial and
            Enterprise Sector Adjustment Loan (FESAL), which the Bank
            intends to submit to the Executive Directors for approval in
            the second or third quarter of FY95. The Agreement was
            implemented without direct official support by drawing down
            Bulgaria's international reserves to less than two
            months of merchandise imports. Bank and IMF support for the
            DDSR agreement will help replenish Bulgaria's reserves
            to a level more appropriate for a small open economy.
